text: Coming up next is the Science Fiction Radio Show, so stay with us. This is the Science Fiction Radio Show, a commentary on science fiction and fantasy. And here are your hosts. This is Daryl Lane and Bill Vernon. Elsbreg de Camp's career as a writer of science fiction and fantasy is in its fifth decade. He started back in the late 1930s in the pulp magazines and has written continuously ever since. His collaborations with Fletcher Pratt occupy an important place in the body of his work. Among others, these would include the Harold Shea stories, The Incomplete Enchanter, The Castle of Iron, and Wall of Serpents. Another of his better known books is Less Darkness Fall, an account of a modern man who ends up in 6th century Rome trying to keep civilization alive as barbarism sweeps Europe. In recent years, De Camp has gotten involved in the Conan stories of Robert E. Howard and has written some rousing sword and sorcery. We asked De Camp to recall for us his beginnings as a writer. Well, in 1937 and 8, I was working in Scranton, Pennsylvania as principal of the School of Inventing and Patenting of the International Correspondents. And I had a friend in New York, an old college roommate of mine named John Clark, who was out of a job and looking for a lot of stuff. And in order to continue to eat, he, who was a faithful reader of the science fiction magazine that I was in that time, wrote a couple of stories. And I used to come in, oh, once or twice a month to New York, and I'd stay at his apartment and sit up late and plot a couple of these stories. So I gave him some help with them. He sent them to Andrew Cremaine and the editor of Astounding, and he sold them. So I thought, why can't I? So, having spent his time in Scranton, I wrote a couple and sent them in. To my surprise, they were lost. He continued to sell an occasional story to the pulp magazines while working at his regular pulp magazines. But then something happened to change him into a full-time writer. At the end of 1939, he was working as one of the editors on a trade journal in New York. And I got fired in an economy purge. So instead of sitting around with a fiddling editorial job, I would have a free list. I think that if I spent five hours a week on my own time writing and made a certain amount of money, if I could spend 50 hours a week at it, make 10 to 15 a month. Well, of course, there's a fallacy. It's gone into a law of diminishing return. But nevertheless, I took the plunge and found that in freelancing, I earned about as much as I had been doing. And I could be my own, work at my own pace, work sitting down, and work out all my old clothes. So, except for a couple of temporary jobs, I was a second worker of war in which I was in the Naval Reserve. I've been at it for since. De Camp is a professional writer in the truest sense of the word. He writes almost books on engineering to the definitive history of the Scopes trial, biography of Charles Darwin for juveniles. Of course, remember that although people generally refer to me as a science fiction writer, the reason is mainly that I made my early reputation in that field. Actually, fiction is only about half of my output, the rest being science, history, biography, literary journalism, and so on. And of the fictional half, aside from five historical novels that I've written, about half is science fiction in the strict sense and half is fantasy. So only about a quarter of my output is really science fiction in the strict sense. More on L. Sprague de Camp next time. This has been the Science Fiction Radio Show, a production of the Permian Basin Science Fiction Association, produced in conjunction with Odessa College in Odessa, Texas. Women, especially when you watch these reports there are images of biological learnings of the pre-meditization was they're encouraged to have this community to have other ideas and computers to have black aliens, but apparently we've got reduced ros't predricians with art titles in the same расPPOS taken along for the quality of the research. But this之前 stayed a place, Coming up next is the Science Fiction Radio Show. Stay with us. This is the Science Fiction Radio Show, a commentary on science fiction and fantasy. And here are your hosts. This is Bill Vernon and Daryl Lane. Humor is not common in science fiction and fantasy. That's understandable. Traditionally, science fiction is concerned with spaceships, aliens, high adventure. So much adventure and excitement that humor would seem out of place. But noted science fiction and fantasy author L. Sprague de Cam thinks that humor and science fiction can mix very well. Well, all I can say is that it is true that there aren't a great many humorous stories in that field. But then, of course, there aren't a great many humorous stories in any genre of fiction. Some people do it and some people don't. Now, back in before the Second World War, pardon me, I'm not that old quite yet. But before the Second World War, of the active science fiction writers in the country, there were only two who were considered humorous science fiction writers. And I was one and Henry Kuttner was the other. Curiously enough, both Henry and I, in our private lives, were rather serious, solemn fellows. Much of De Camp's science fiction and fantasy is humorous. In one of the Harold Shea stories, collected in The Incomplete Enchanter, De Camp delights in constructing episodes that show the incongruity of a 20th century man trying to survive in the world of Spencer's Fairy Queen. There's some funny stuff in there. At one point, Shea and his companions are captured by the blatant beast, who threatens to devour them if they don't entertain him by resetting an epic. But all the epic Shea starts to recite, such as Beowulf, the blatant beast already knows. In desperation, Shea launches into the Ballad of Eskimo Nell, a bawdy drinking song that goes on forever. In the first place, Shea is mortified by having to recite such a thing in front of his female companion. But the blatant beast lets his captives go and walks off slowly into the woods, shaking its monstrous head. It's ridiculously incongruous, of course. And De Camp maintains that's where the humor comes from. One of the basic elements of humor, in my estimation, is the element of surprise or incongruity. In other words, a derby hat on a London businessman is not funny because they all wear them. But a derby hat on Julius Caesar is, you see, because it's incongruous. And that is a very considerable factor in humor. We asked De Camp if there was anything that wouldn't mix well with humor. Maybe heroic sword and sorcery material like the Conan stories. Well, you couldn't get the same effect that Robert Howard did with his Conan because in Robert Howard's original Conan stories, there is hardly any humor. Only in a couple of stories is there a faint gleam of it here and there. And when I collaborate with present-day Conan stories, with, let us say, Carter, why, he has to call me down now and then because I just have a natural tendency to stick a little humor in now and then. I've been doing it so long, it comes natural. But it should not be done because it spoils the general effect. Now, as for my own stories in that genre, well, I have no hesitation about putting humor in and putting humor in. And my heroes are, in general, not supermen. They have to be pretty able fellows, but I try to make them realistic. That is, with the usual assortment of virtues and vices and strengths and weaknesses. Because that's the kind of character that I personally find it easier to believe in when I read it. Humor takes many forms in DeCamp's work. He can use gentle satire, for instance, in a book like The Great Fetish. And don't forget his collection of humorous barroom tall tales done with Fletcher Pratt, tales from Gavegan's Bar. We're seeing more humor in science fiction today. I suspect L. Sprague DeCamp's influence is being felt. More next time on L. Sprague DeCamp. This has been the Science Fiction Radio Show, a production of the Permian Basin Science Fiction Association, produced in conjunction with Odessa College in Odessa, Texas. The Science Fiction Radio Show, a production of the Permian Basin Science Fiction Association, of the Permian Basin Science Fiction Association. Coming up next is the Science Fiction Radio Show, so stay with us. This is the Science Fiction Radio Show, a commentary on science fiction and fantasy. And here are your hosts. This is Daryl Lane. And Bill Vernon. One of the most successful collaborations in the field of science fantasy was the team of Fletcher Pratt and L. Sprague DeCamp. During the late 30s and through the 40s, they wrote a series of humorous stories about a young man named Harold Shea. Shea theorizes that there are an infinite number of worlds that exist all around us. And he finds a way to get to them using symbolic logic. He visits a number of fantastic places. The world of Norse mythology, for instance, and the world of Spencer's Fairy Queen. Sprague DeCamp says that a friend named John Clark introduced him to Fletcher Pratt in the late 1930s. Fletcher was at that time an established and active writer and I was a struggling young pro, you might say. So, John said to me, hey, Fletcher says he would like to see you. He has an idea for some stories. So, I went around to Fletcher's and he proposed that he and I collaborate on a series of stories based upon this far-out theory that you can slip into any universe you want to by manipulating the symbols of symbolic logic. I had been studying symbolic logic a little with all its cuter symbols and things. So, okay, we went to it. And that is how the five Harold Shea stories originated. The Shea stories appeared in pulp magazines beginning in 1940. They were later collected in three books. The Incomplete Enchanter, The Castle of Iron, and Wall of Serpents. The alternate universes Shea enters are fantasy worlds where magic works. But they're all consistent logical places once you accept their magical framework. Right. Shea finds out that matches or guns just don't operate in these worlds. The Camp says that such consistency is important to fantasy. Both Fletcher and I had long since agreed that, right from the start, that the most effective, that in writing fantasy, you have to be even more careful about internal consistency than you do in writing a realistic story. Because the reader's credulity is already stretched like a rubber band, you see. And if you put extra strain on it by having some obvious contradiction, it's going to snap. At that point, you'll probably stop reading. The Camp explains how he and Pratt came up with their alternate worlds. Actually, I've always been a very heavy reader. I was reading Darwin's Origin of Species through at the age of seven, you know, and things like that. And I had a pretty good historical and mythological knowledge. But actually, for the roaring trumpet, Fletcher knew a good deal more about that than I, because he was an enthusiast for the northern thing, as William Morris called it. And it belonged to a group that got together in Boston and read Icelandic sagas to each other in the original. Well, therefore, he was way ahead of me in the matter of Norse mythology. Then the second story was laid in the world of Spencer's Fairy Queen. And I had never read the Fairy Queen, so I sat down and dutifully plowed right through it. I never did have quite the enthusiasm for it that Fletcher did. I found it pretty tedious for long stretches. But nevertheless, he thought highly of it, and he went through it. And then for the third one, why I knew something about Ariosto's Orlando Furioso, although I'd never read it through, but it wasn't very difficult to get hold of a set and read it. And that furnished the material there. Well, then we, after the Second World War, we sent Harold to the world of the Finnish Kallivala. And that was simply a matter of getting the Everyman's Library edition and reading through that and taking notes. And we finally had him end up where he'd wanted to go all along, which is in the mythological Ireland of Coochollan and Queen Maeve. And I already knew a fair amount about that, but I read up some more, and so we got the stories. Next time, we'll have more on Elsberg de Camp. This has been the Science Fiction Radio Show, a production of the Permian Basin Science Fiction Association, produced in conjunction with Odessa College in Odessa, Texas. This has been the Science Fiction Radio Show,

segments.text: Coming up next is the Science Fiction Radio Show, so stay with us.
This is the Science Fiction Radio Show, a commentary on science fiction and fantasy.
And here are your hosts.
This is Daryl Lane and Bill Vernon.
Elsbreg de Camp's career as a writer of science fiction and fantasy is in its fifth decade.
He started back in the late 1930s in the pulp magazines and has written continuously ever since.
His collaborations with Fletcher Pratt occupy an important place in the body of his work.
Among others, these would include the Harold Shea stories, The Incomplete Enchanter, The Castle of Iron, and Wall of Serpents.
Another of his better known books is Less Darkness Fall, an account of a modern man who ends up in 6th century Rome trying to keep civilization alive as barbarism sweeps Europe.
In recent years, De Camp has gotten involved in the Conan stories of Robert E. Howard and has written some rousing sword and sorcery.
We asked De Camp to recall for us his beginnings as a writer.
Well, in 1937 and 8, I was working in Scranton, Pennsylvania as principal of the School of Inventing and Patenting of the International Correspondents.
And I had a friend in New York, an old college roommate of mine named John Clark, who was out of a job and looking for a lot of stuff.
And in order to continue to eat, he, who was a faithful reader of the science fiction magazine that I was in that time, wrote a couple of stories.
And I used to come in, oh, once or twice a month to New York, and I'd stay at his apartment and sit up late and plot a couple of these stories.
So I gave him some help with them.
He sent them to Andrew Cremaine and the editor of Astounding, and he sold them.
So I thought, why can't I?
So, having spent his time in Scranton, I wrote a couple and sent them in.
To my surprise, they were lost.
He continued to sell an occasional story to the pulp magazines while working at his regular pulp magazines.
But then something happened to change him into a full-time writer.
At the end of 1939, he was working as one of the editors on a trade journal in New York.
And I got fired in an economy purge.
So instead of sitting around with a fiddling editorial job, I would have a free list.
I think that if I spent five hours a week on my own time writing and made a certain amount of money,
if I could spend 50 hours a week at it, make 10 to 15 a month.
Well, of course, there's a fallacy.
It's gone into a law of diminishing return.
But nevertheless, I took the plunge and found that in freelancing,
I earned about as much as I had been doing.
And I could be my own, work at my own pace, work sitting down, and work out all my old clothes.
So, except for a couple of temporary jobs, I was a second worker of war in which I was in the Naval Reserve.
I've been at it for since.
De Camp is a professional writer in the truest sense of the word.
He writes almost books on engineering to the definitive history of the Scopes trial,
biography of Charles Darwin for juveniles.
Of course, remember that although people generally refer to me as a science fiction writer,
the reason is mainly that I made my early reputation in that field.
Actually, fiction is only about half of my output,
the rest being science, history, biography, literary journalism, and so on.
And of the fictional half, aside from five historical novels that I've written,
about half is science fiction in the strict sense and half is fantasy.
So only about a quarter of my output is really science fiction in the strict sense.
More on L. Sprague de Camp next time.
This has been the Science Fiction Radio Show,

Coming up next is the Science Fiction Radio Show.
Stay with us.
This is the Science Fiction Radio Show, a commentary on science fiction and fantasy.
And here are your hosts.
This is Bill Vernon and Daryl Lane.
Humor is not common in science fiction and fantasy.
That's understandable.
Traditionally, science fiction is concerned with spaceships, aliens, high adventure.
So much adventure and excitement that humor would seem out of place.
But noted science fiction and fantasy author L. Sprague de Cam thinks that humor and science fiction can mix very well.
Well, all I can say is that it is true that there aren't a great many humorous stories in that field.
But then, of course, there aren't a great many humorous stories in any genre of fiction.
Some people do it and some people don't.
Now, back in before the Second World War, pardon me, I'm not that old quite yet.
But before the Second World War, of the active science fiction writers in the country,
there were only two who were considered humorous science fiction writers.
And I was one and Henry Kuttner was the other.
Curiously enough, both Henry and I, in our private lives, were rather serious, solemn fellows.
Much of De Camp's science fiction and fantasy is humorous.
In one of the Harold Shea stories, collected in The Incomplete Enchanter,
De Camp delights in constructing episodes that show the incongruity of a 20th century man
trying to survive in the world of Spencer's Fairy Queen.
There's some funny stuff in there.
At one point, Shea and his companions are captured by the blatant beast,
who threatens to devour them if they don't entertain him by resetting an epic.
But all the epic Shea starts to recite, such as Beowulf, the blatant beast already knows.
In desperation, Shea launches into the Ballad of Eskimo Nell,
a bawdy drinking song that goes on forever.
In the first place, Shea is mortified by having to recite such a thing in front of his female companion.
But the blatant beast lets his captives go and walks off slowly into the woods, shaking its monstrous head.
It's ridiculously incongruous, of course.
And De Camp maintains that's where the humor comes from.
One of the basic elements of humor, in my estimation, is the element of surprise or incongruity.
In other words, a derby hat on a London businessman is not funny because they all wear them.
But a derby hat on Julius Caesar is, you see, because it's incongruous.
And that is a very considerable factor in humor.
We asked De Camp if there was anything that wouldn't mix well with humor.
Maybe heroic sword and sorcery material like the Conan stories.
Well, you couldn't get the same effect that Robert Howard did with his Conan because in Robert Howard's original Conan stories, there is hardly any humor.
Only in a couple of stories is there a faint gleam of it here and there.

And when I collaborate with present-day Conan stories, with, let us say, Carter, why, he has to call me down now and then because I just have a natural tendency to stick a little humor in now and then.
I've been doing it so long, it comes natural.
But it should not be done because it spoils the general effect.
Now, as for my own stories in that genre, well, I have no hesitation about putting humor in and putting humor in.
And my heroes are, in general, not supermen.
They have to be pretty able fellows, but I try to make them realistic.
That is, with the usual assortment of virtues and vices and strengths and weaknesses.
Because that's the kind of character that I personally find it easier to believe in when I read it.
Humor takes many forms in DeCamp's work.
He can use gentle satire, for instance, in a book like The Great Fetish.
And don't forget his collection of humorous barroom tall tales done with Fletcher Pratt, tales from Gavegan's Bar.
We're seeing more humor in science fiction today.
I suspect L. Sprague DeCamp's influence is being felt.
More next time on L. Sprague DeCamp.
This has been the Science Fiction Radio Show, a production of the Permian Basin Science Fiction Association,
produced in conjunction with Odessa College in Odessa, Texas.

Coming up next is the Science Fiction Radio Show, so stay with us.
This is the Science Fiction Radio Show, a commentary on science fiction and fantasy.
And here are your hosts.
This is Daryl Lane.
And Bill Vernon.
One of the most successful collaborations in the field of science fantasy was the team of Fletcher Pratt and L. Sprague DeCamp.
During the late 30s and through the 40s, they wrote a series of humorous stories about a young man named Harold Shea.
Shea theorizes that there are an infinite number of worlds that exist all around us.
And he finds a way to get to them using symbolic logic.
He visits a number of fantastic places.
The world of Norse mythology, for instance, and the world of Spencer's Fairy Queen.
Sprague DeCamp says that a friend named John Clark introduced him to Fletcher Pratt in the late 1930s.
Fletcher was at that time an established and active writer and I was a struggling young pro, you might say.
So, John said to me, hey, Fletcher says he would like to see you.
He has an idea for some stories.

So, I went around to Fletcher's and he proposed that he and I collaborate on a series of stories based upon this far-out theory that you can slip into any universe you want to by manipulating the symbols of symbolic logic.
I had been studying symbolic logic a little with all its cuter symbols and things.
So, okay, we went to it.
And that is how the five Harold Shea stories originated.
The Shea stories appeared in pulp magazines beginning in 1940.
They were later collected in three books.
The Incomplete Enchanter, The Castle of Iron, and Wall of Serpents.
The alternate universes Shea enters are fantasy worlds where magic works.
But they're all consistent logical places once you accept their magical framework.
Right.
Shea finds out that matches or guns just don't operate in these worlds.
The Camp says that such consistency is important to fantasy.
Both Fletcher and I had long since agreed that, right from the start, that the most effective, that in writing fantasy,
you have to be even more careful about internal consistency than you do in writing a realistic story.
Because the reader's credulity is already stretched like a rubber band, you see.
And if you put extra strain on it by having some obvious contradiction, it's going to snap.
At that point, you'll probably stop reading.
The Camp explains how he and Pratt came up with their alternate worlds.
Actually, I've always been a very heavy reader.
I was reading Darwin's Origin of Species through at the age of seven, you know, and things like that.
And I had a pretty good historical and mythological knowledge.
But actually, for the roaring trumpet, Fletcher knew a good deal more about that than I,
because he was an enthusiast for the northern thing, as William Morris called it.
And it belonged to a group that got together in Boston and read Icelandic sagas to each other in the original.
Well, therefore, he was way ahead of me in the matter of Norse mythology.
Then the second story was laid in the world of Spencer's Fairy Queen.
And I had never read the Fairy Queen, so I sat down and dutifully plowed right through it.
I never did have quite the enthusiasm for it that Fletcher did.
I found it pretty tedious for long stretches.
But nevertheless, he thought highly of it, and he went through it.
And then for the third one, why I knew something about Ariosto's Orlando Furioso,
although I'd never read it through, but it wasn't very difficult to get hold of a set and read it.
And that furnished the material there.
Well, then we, after the Second World War, we sent Harold to the world of the Finnish Kallivala.
And that was simply a matter of getting the Everyman's Library edition and reading through that and taking notes.
And we finally had him end up where he'd wanted to go all along,
which is in the mythological Ireland of Coochollan and Queen Maeve.
And I already knew a fair amount about that, but I read up some more, and so we got the stories.
Next time, we'll have more on Elsberg de Camp.
This has been the Science Fiction Radio Show,
a production of the Permian Basin Science Fiction Association,
